section: The Customer is responsible for paying i-on the recurring monthly fee in the amount of $450. The Customer is responsible for paying the recurring monthly fees at their discretion and convenience. The Customer acknowledges that failure to pay such fees in a timely manner will result in the interruption or discontinuation of services for the Hosted Site.
explanation: The phrase 'at their discretion and convenience' contradicts the implication that fees must be paid 'in a timely manner.' This creates ambiguity about the payment terms and allows for interpretation that significantly delays the payment.

section: This Agreement shall automatically be renewed for one (1) or more one (1) month periods unless either the Customer or i-on gives notice to the other party of its intention not to renew the 4 Agreement, which notice must be given not less than fifteen (15) days before the end of the respective initial or renewal term. Either party may terminate this Agreement without cause at any time effective upon fifteen (15) days' written notice.
explanation: The text implies that the agreement can be terminated at anytime without cause, but at the same time, it mentions that the agreement is automatically renewed for one month if the customer does not provide notice to cancel. This is a contradiction. It is also not structured properly.

section: i-on will be liable under any circumstances for any lost profits or other consequential damages, even if i-on has been advised as to the possibility of such damages. i-on's liability for damages to the Customer for any cause whatsoever, regardless of the form of action, and whether in contract or in tort, including negligence, shall be limited to one (1) month's fees and the remaining portion of any prepaid fees.
explanation: The phrase 'i-on will be liable under any circumstances for any lost profits or other consequential damages' is immediately contradicted by 'i-on's liability for damages to the Customer for any cause whatsoever...shall be limited to one (1) month's fees and the remaining portion of any prepaid fees.' The first statement suggests unlimited liability for lost profits, while the second significantly restricts the total liability.
